questions.question_text: During online, collaborative meeting sessions, a project team is consistently in consensus, which is causing a creativity roadblock. Which of the following can the facilitator do to minimize this issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. Use a whiteboard.

Using a whiteboard in an online collaborative meeting can help stimulate creativity and encourage participants to generate diverse ideas. A virtual whiteboard allows the facilitator and team members to visually brainstorm, draw diagrams, and jot down ideas in real time. It provides a platform for participants to contribute their thoughts and visually represent their ideas, which can help break the consensus and promote new perspectives.

Selected Answer: A
A. Enable Chat.

Your team is sitting listening, not much collaboration in that. 2nd best is Use a whiteboard.

I agree with A because if the facilitator is presenting and people have questions about the overall meeting, enabling chat is best in this scenario so individual can clarify and understand what is at hand. Whiteboard I was leaning toward because individuals can chime in and clarify their intents. Survey would be seen after the meeting is over unless you're using something like TEAMS that enable almost all the function stated in the choices, but this topic seems to be pointing at bare bone video chat.

Selected Answer: B
Answer is Surveys. 
Surveys provide a structured and confidential way to gather individual input, which can then be used to encourage more open and diverse discussions during the meeting.

I would say B surveys. This would force independent ideas/answers without external influence. Basically it would avoid group thinking which manifests itself as always being in consensus during the meetings.

comments.content: I initially thought the same. However I looked at the Dion Study guide and it directly mentions whiteboards or virtual whiteboards as a means for people to share their creative ideas. Seems like D is the BEST way to go in spite of the questions slight vagueness leaving B to be a possibility.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
It's B, There is no such thing as Time-Tracking Log in Project+.

Selected Answer: A
The answer is A. Time-tracking log.

The time-tracking log is the most accurate record of the contractor's overtime hours. It will show the exact dates and times that the contractor worked overtime, as well as the reason for the overtime. This information is essential for the management team to understand the extent of the issue and to take appropriate action.

The issue log is not the best tool to use in this case because it is used to track known issues that are affecting the project. The overtime hours are not an issue yet, but they could become an issue if they are not addressed.

Selected Answer: A
This is a time and work issue, so it belongs to time tracking

Core Elements of a Phase-Gate Review:

It occurs at the end of a project phase/segment
It acts as a quality control checkpoint before proceeding
It requires formal approval to move to the next phase
It evaluates both completed work and readiness for next phase
It results in a go/no-go decision
This is definitely C.

Selected Answer: C
C - A phase-gate review is a structured process where a project manager assesses the completion of a project phase before moving on to the next one. It involves evaluating whether the work produced in the previous segment meets the required standards and if the necessary resources are available for the next phase. This review helps ensure that the project is on track and that potential issues or gaps are identified and addressed before proceeding further. Therefore, in this scenario, coordinating a phase-gate review would be the appropriate action for the project manager.

Selected Answer: C
This is a tricky one but I will go for C
C:The phase gate process is a technique that is used to guide a project from conception to launch. It requires a review of each project stage before moving on to the next. In the phase gate review process, specific criteria must be met to determine the success of a phase and the ongoing viability of a project

Perform a gap analysis can be a useful technique to identify gaps or discrepancies between desired and actual performance, but it may not cover the entire scope of assessing work quality or resource availability.

Selected Answer: B
B. Perform a gap analysis.

Performing a gap analysis involves comparing the current state of the project (work produced, resources available, etc.) with the desired or expected state. In this case, the project manager can conduct a gap analysis to evaluate if the work produced in the previous segment meets the desired standards and if there are any gaps or discrepancies that need to be addressed before proceeding to the next segment. The analysis can help identify any shortcomings, deviations, or areas for improvement, both in terms of the quality of work and resource availability.
